customer_addr:
71 S. Country Club Road
DECATUR, IL 62521

citations.narrative:
On the morning of October 26, 2024 at approximately 7:30 am a keeper on thier morning checks found that both of the 10
yr old Screech Owls were killed overnight by what the zoo thinks is a possible mink. There were no other birds in the
primary enclosure, only the male and female Screech Owls. There were no bird carcasses found inside the enclosure,
only some feathers located beside a 1.5 x 2 inch gap under the wooden based/wire fence along the back of the primary
enclosure where it appears the predator gained entry into the enclosure.
While there is 2 x 2 inch wire fencing covering the entire dirt floor, there was nothing connecting the 1 x 2 inch side wire
with a wooden base to the floor wire. It appears the predator was able to dig under the wall and make a 1.5 x 2 inch gap
between the base of the wall and floor wire and gain entry. There were no other gaps or holes anywhere else in the
enclosure where a predator could have gained entry or exited with the owl carcasses or any tracks or other clues to
identify what predator came into the enclosure and killed the Screech Owls. The zoo has had problems with mink within
the past month and currently have been trying to remove them from the property and are now going to seek assistance
from other sources. On October 26, 2024 all of the other birds housed outside in other enclosures in the zoo have been
moved inside to winter housing.
The lack of secure predator proof enclosures for bird species can cause possible stress to the animals by allowing
predators to enter the primary enclosures to harass, injure or kill the regulated species.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
On the morning of October 26, 2024 at approximately 7:30 am a keeper on thier morning checks found that both of the 10 
yr old Screech Owls were killed overnight by what the zoo thinks is a possible mink. There were no other birds in the 
primary enclosure, only the male and female Screech Owls. There were no bird carcasses found inside the enclosure, 
only some feathers located beside a 1.5 x 2 inch gap under the wooden based/wire fence along the back of the primary 
enclosure where it appears the predator gained entry into the enclosure. 
 
 While there is 2 x 2 inch wire fencing covering the entire dirt floor, there was nothing connecting the 1 x 2 inch side wire 
with a wooden base to the floor wire. It appears the predator was able to dig under the wall and make a 1.5 x 2 inch gap 
between the base of the wall and floor wire and gain entry. There were no other gaps or holes anywhere else in the 
enclosure where a predator could have gained entry or exited with the owl carcasses or any tracks or other clues to 
identify what predator came into the enclosure and killed the Screech Owls. The zoo has had problems with mink within 
the past month and currently have been trying to remove them from the property and are now going to seek assistance 
from other sources. On October 26, 2024 all of the other birds housed outside in other enclosures in the zoo have been 
moved inside to winter housing.  
 
The lack of secure predator proof enclosures for bird species can cause possible stress to the animals by allowing 
predators to enter the primary enclosures to harass, injure or kill the regulated species. 
 
 Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering 
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
 n
